components.name: eye
joins: bottom edge can be sewn to other items

instructions.as_text:
Back Half
With green yarn, CO 8 sts, join to work in the round.
Round 1: (K1, kfb) four times. 12 sts.
Round 2: K1, (m1, k3) three times, m1, k2. 16 sts.
Round 3: K all.
Round 4: (M1, k2) eight times. 24 sts.
Round 5: K all.
Turn to begin working back and forth in rows
(you’ll need to continue treating the needles as
if you’re working in the round for at least a few
more rows, until it’s opened up more).
Work rows below, stopping after a WS row at the
point when the piece measures 4–5.5" across
bottom, or however big you want your eyes.
Row 6 (WS): P2tog, p to last 2 sts, p2tog. 22 sts.
Row 7 (RS): K4, (m1, k2) eight times, k2. 30 sts.
Row 8 (WS): P all.
Row 9 (RS): K all.
Row 10 (WS): P all.
Row 11 (RS): K3, (k3, m1) seven times, k6. 37 sts.
Row 12 (WS): P all.
Row 13 (RS): K all.
Row 14 (WS): P all.
Row 15 (RS): K4, (k3, m1) nine times, k6. 46 sts.
Row 16 (WS): P all.
Row 17 (RS): K all.
Row 18 (WS): P all.
Row 19 (RS): K3, (k4, m1) nine times, k7. 55 sts.
Row 20 (WS): P all.
Row 21 (RS): K all.
Row 22 (WS): P all.
Front Half
Make note of number of last row worked (WS row).
Take that number (total rows worked) and divide it
by 3. If that’s not a whole number, round up to the
next whole number. This number = x.
Switch to white yarn and begin working the rows
below, starting with the number row beneath the
last row you worked. (So, the highest number was
the last green row, and now you’ll count back down
from there. Eg, if you ended with row 14, begin with
row 13 below, skipping past rows 21–14.)
Work like that, downwards through the rows below,
until x rows have been worked in white.
Only if using the optional red:
Switch to red yarn and continue in pattern for
x-1 more rows.
Move to instructions below, but when switching
from red to black—if this is happening after the
piece has been rejoined in the round—slip the
first stitch of the first black round if it’s meant
to be a knit stitch; if the first stitch is k2tog,
then work that decrease in red, slip the next
stitch, then switch to black.
Switch to black yarn and continue in pattern down
to row 1 at the end (7 sts remain).
Row 21 (RS): K all.
Row 20 (WS): P all.
Row 19 (RS): K3, (k3, k2tog) nine times, k7. 46 sts.
Row 18 (WS): P all.
Row 17 (RS): K all.
Row 16 (WS): P all.
Row 15 (RS): K4, (k2, k2tog) nine times, k6. 37 sts.
Row 14 (WS): P all.
Row 13 (RS): K all.
Row 12 (WS): P all.
Row 11 (RS): K3, (k2, k2tog) seven times, k6. 30 sts.
Row 10 (WS): P all.
Row 9 (RS): K all.
Row 8 (WS): P all.
Row 7 (RS): K3, (k2tog, k1) eight times, k3. 22 sts.
Join to other side to begin working in the round.
Round 6: K1, pass last st of last row over this st, k1,
m1, k to last st, m1, k1. 23 sts.
Round 5: K all.
Round 4: (K2tog, k1) seven times, k2tog. 15 sts.
Round 3: K all.
Round 2: (K2tog, k2) three times, k2tog, k1. 11 sts.
Round 1: (K2tog, k1) three times, k2tog. 7 sts.
Finishing
Break yarn, thread onto yarn needle, bring through
live sts then through hole to inside, and pull closed.
Thread CO tail onto yarn needle, weave yarn around
through CO sts, bring yarn through hole to inside,
and pull hole closed.
Weave in all the other ends just a little if you didn't
do it while knitting, to secure them to the inside of
the piece. Yarn ends don't need to be trimmed—in
fact, they're useful as part of the stuffing!
Tie the CO and ending tails together on the inside
of the eye, tightly so that the back and front touch
if you plan to use just a little stuffing, or more
loosely if you want to stuff the eyes a lot and make
them more 3-dimensional.
Use white yarn and the yarn needle to stitch a small
circle or star of embroidery in the upper right of
the edge of the black part. Note that you may prefer
to wait and do this after the eyes are attached to an
item, so you can place the spots better in context.
Repeat everything for the second eye.
Block the eyes by soaking, squeezing water out
in a towel, and laying them flat to dry.

steps.howto_summary: cast on and start the back half
knit the back half of plain colors
knit the front half with a different color
weave in the yarn ends and post process

text.full_text: This is an any-gauge pattern for frog eyes which can be sewn onto the top of a hat, balaclava, or headband. It’s kind of meant to pair with my old balaclava pattern Freak Out! , which has now been made free, so go grab that and you’ll have everything you need to make a frog mask! Make the Freak Out piece (also designed for any gauge) in green yarn, then use the same yarn for the eyes, along with white, black, and optional red yarns in the same weight. The way this pattern works to get any size eyes with any weight yarn (with no gauge swatch!) is to start at the center of the back side of the eye, work your way outwards until it’s the size you want, then switch to the front-eye colors and work your way inwards, mirroring the back half.
text.description: This is an any-gauge pattern for frog eyes which can be sewn onto the top of a hat, balaclava, or headband.
